events.title: Birth of Alexander Borodin
events.summary: Borodin was born in Saint Petersburg as an illegitimate son of a 62-year-old Georgian nobleman and a 25-year-old married Russian woman. Due to his birth circumstances, he was registered as the son of one of the nobleman's serfs, which determined his upbringing as a commoner. His Georgian father emancipated him from serfdom when he was 7, ensuring a comfortable life for Borodin and his mother.
events.fun_version: Borodin's origin story sounds like a plot twist straight from a Georgian soap opera! Born in the heart of Saint Petersburg as an illegitimate son of a 62-year-old Georgian nobleman and a 25-year-old married Russian woman, this lad came into the world as an unintentional surprise! He was registered as the son of a serf, which determined his upbringing as a commoner. Luckily for him, his father emancipated him from serfdom when he was just 7, ensuring a comfortable life for Borodin and his mother.

events.title: Education and Career in Chemistry
events.summary: In 1850, Borodin enrolled in the Medical–Surgical Academy in Saint Petersburg, later becoming a professor of chemistry there. He established medical courses for women in 1872 and was highly respected for his research in chemistry, particularly his work on aldehydes.
events.fun_version: In 1850, Borodin enrolled in the Medical–Surgical Academy in Saint Petersburg, later becoming a professor of chemistry there! In 1872, he bravely established medical courses for women, proving once and for all that women can well, do the science things too. His research into aldehydes was so revered that many thought he was simply trying to find the best way to impress his chemistry class.

events.title: Marriage to Ekaterina Protopopova
events.summary: Borodin married Ekaterina Protopopova, a pianist, in 1863. Together, they adopted several daughters.
events.fun_version: In 1863, Borodin decided to tie the knot with Ekaterina Protopopova, a pianist – because who wouldn’t want a wedding with symphonic honeymoon tunes? Instead of having a pet, they opted for the drama of adopting several daughters!

events.title: Composing Symphony No. 1
events.summary: While taking composition lessons from Mily Balakirev, Borodin began working on his Symphony No. 1 in E-flat major in 1862, which was first performed in 1869.
events.fun_version: While learning composition from the great Mily Balakirev, Borodin decided to take a break from his usual menu of composing potato salad recipes and began crafting his Symphony No. 1 in E-flat major in 1862, which had its grand debut in 1869.

events.title: Performance of Symphony No. 1 in Germany
events.summary: Borodin's Symphony No. 1 was notably performed in Germany, thanks to Franz Liszt's arrangements. This event helped establish Borodin's reputation beyond the Russian Empire, showcasing his talent to a wider audience.
events.fun_version: Borodin's Symphony No. 1 made waves in Germany, thanks to Franz Liszt, who served it with a side of sauerkraut! This event not only introduced Borodin to the world but also helped him shimmy his way past the Russian Empire's borders, proving that even Russian composers can party it up in Europe!

events.title: Completion of Opera Prince Igor
events.summary: Borodin worked on the opera Prince Igor, which is considered to be his most significant work, during 1868. It was left incomplete at his death but later completed posthumously by Rimsky-Korsakov and Glazunov.
events.fun_version: Borodin was hard at work on an opera called Prince Igor in 1868, but he never quite made it to the finish line as it was left incomplete at his death. Thankfully, Rimsky-Korsakov and Glazunov swooped in to rescue the score posthumously.

events.title: Death of Alexander Borodin
events.summary: Borodin died suddenly during a ball at the academy where he taught, leaving behind several unfinished works.
events.fun_version: Borodin decided to leave the party early—so early that he forgot to pack his unfinished symphonies! While he was enjoying the academy ball, he made an unexpected departure. Talk about an unexpected encore!

works.title: My Songs are Filled with Poison
In the Steppes of Central Asia
